Award.AwardTitle: EarthCube IA: Collaborative Proposal: Enhancing Paleontological and Neontological Data Discovery API
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding future environmental change requires researchers to access and integrate data from the geological and biological sciences, in order to answer questions about how environmental change will affect life on Earth. In many cases the data needed to answer these questions already exists but, unfortunately, technology has not kept pace with research needs. This places increasing demands on researchers, who have to search for and download data from multiple separate online databases; compile published information from many different literature sources; and track down specimens housed in museum and other collections scattered around the world. The time needed to search and retrieve this information is enormous and, once found, the data often have to be standardized before they can be used. This project will tackle this problem by developing software tools to connect three established, well-supported, and critically important data sources: the Paleobiology Database (PBDB, paleontological, literature based), iDigPaleo (paleontological, specimen based) and iDigBio (neontological, specimen based). This project will allow users of any one of these databases to access and query the others at the same time, returning a much richer, combined set of data to the user. Connecting these resources will open up a whole host of research questions that are currently difficult to answer, even by multiple researchers working as a team. The development of this system will allow scientists to ask and answer new research questions affecting fields as diverse as biogeographic/niche modeling, systematics, functional morphology, evolutionary biology, ecology, climatology, conservation biology, oceanography, and petroleum geology. This project will fundamentally change the nature of the research questions that can be addressed by the scientific community.

The connectivity between modern and fossil, and specimen and literature-based resources does not currently exist. The digital infrastructure provided by the composite ePANDDA application programming interfaces (APIs) will streamline and normalize data acquisition, including retrieval from disparate data sources, and will facilitate coordination with future data initiatives. Rather than creating another portal for the aggregation of data, ePANDDA will unify results that normally would have required multiple searches on numerous platforms. For the researcher, this eliminates a significant barrier to data collection and processing. Researchers will now have the ability to collaborate across disciplinary boundaries to study earth system processes and the nature of biotic response to environmental change across both space and time. Linking publications to specimens will enrich the potential of museum collections and augment their value for both research and education. The ePANDDA project also provides an opportunity to build collaborative programs that leverage existing education and outreach activities in addition to the primary research goals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ePANDDA: Enhancing PAleontological and Neontological Data Discovery API project developed application programming interfaces (APIs) that integrate the paleontological and modern biological data resources of the Paleobiology Database (PBDB) and the integrated Digitized Biocollections (iDigBio). Collaboration among these database initiatives has provided a rare opportunity to tackle the challenges of combining database underlying structures that were created in different ways to do different things with the data. By centralizing access and aligning different data sets using common parameters, ePANDDA has made it possible for anyone to access and use data from both resources. 

History of the award: The Geological Society of America (GSA) lead Principle Investigator (PI) was Dena Smith, until Smith became a program officer at NSF, when Park Boush became the substitute PI. The other PIs determined that PI Jocelyn Sessa should take over GSA’s duties, and a subaward from GSA was established to Sessa at the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH) in April 2017. When subawardee Sessa left AMNH for a position at the Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University, a subaward from the GSA to Drexel was established in February, 2018 to cover costs: 1. associated with the scheduling, coordination, and travel reimbursements for the ePANDDA hackathon, which occurred Sept 18-19, 2017 at the Academy of Natural Sciences, and 2. Sessa’s travel to the annual GSA meeting Oct 21-26, 2017, to present about ePANDDA.

The first PI meeting was held in conjunction with the Geological Society of America Annual Meeting in Baltimore, MD in Nov 1-4, 2015. After this initial PI meeting, bi- weekly to monthly virtual meetings of the PIs were held on a regular basis. During these meetings the core team discussed overall project goals, kept the team apprised of each institution’s/partner’s activities and accomplishments, developed team action- items and timelines for accomplishing both short-term and long-term objectives. 

Information about the ePANDDA project is available through the EarthCube website (http://earthcube.org/); the ePANDDA GitHub repository (https://github.com/ePandda), the ePANDDA website (epandda.org), and ePANDDA social media accounts on Facebook and Twitter. Additionally, presentations about ePANDDA and the hackathon are maintained on iDigBio’s website: https://www.idigbio.org/content/epandda-project-increasing-accessibility-digitized-data-paleontological-and- neontological https://www.idigbio.org/wiki/images/1/18/EPANDDA_BerkeleyWrkshp_Gil.pdf https://www.idigbio.org/wiki/index.php/Inaugural_Digital_Data_in_Biodiversity_Research_Conference_Agendahttps://www.idigbio.org/wiki/index.php/2017_ePANDDA_Hackathon. 

The intellectual merit of ePANDDA is significant. By efficiently synthesizing data from across the geological, paleontological, and neontological sciences, ePANDDA fundamentally changed the nature of the research questions that can be addressed by the scientific community. Researchers now have the ability to collaborate across disciplinary boundaries to study earth system processes and the nature of biotic response to environmental change across both space and time. 

The Broader Impacts of ePANDDA are far-reaching. The participating databases are all actively engaged in their own broader impact activities, which include projects that seek to diversify the scientific workforce, provide educational content for K-16 classrooms, and engage citizen scientists of all ages to interact with data resources and tools. Therefore, the ePANDDA project provides an opportunity for the partners to build collaborative programs that leverage existing education and outreach activities in addition to the primary research goals.
